channel.title: Comcast and static ip's
channel.description:
Okay so from what I have been told over the phone and from what I have googled. It is impossible for a resident to get static ip's from Comcast.
Now I have never used no-ip before. Does it make the dynamic ip static? If so, can I still use my wireless connection with no-ip running?
Please give me more information

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:23, topic:455025”][quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=557889.msg4082676#msg4082676 date=1345500896]
why do you say that? They recently went to fiber from what I have heard
[/quote]
Only experience I have had using uVerse was constant outages and slow speeds.[/quote]from what I was told on the phone with them this morning they only go up to 24mb but I would only be doing about a 6mb/12mb package.

cable is more efficient when it comes to not going out during storms and all though imo. I really do wish though I could get an affordable rate with a static ip though as well :s

Read full topic

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

Yeah, it’s like 59.99 $ for the lowest one. I am paying 29.99$ right now for a promotional.

The business lowest one is like 3mb or something. I have 12mb currently for 29.99 for a year so I can’t argue

Read full topic

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:18, topic:455025”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=557889.msg4082470#msg4082470 date=1345489783]
Depending on where you live and how dense the population is you could easily get a static ip from Comcast, I’ve had a static ip since I created this account. Just call up support our go into your local Comcast service store and talk to them about how to obtain a static ip.
[/quote]I did last night they said I would have to upgrade to a business account and I am not about to pay the fees monthly for that one.[/quote]

Even if you buy the lowest tier?

Read full topic

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:12, topic:455025”][quote author=t4 link=topic=557889.msg4081945#msg4081945 date=1345440375]
most leases are a day, 3 days or a week
[/quote]well anyway to get these leases raised up ? :P[/quote]
not really, your isp isn’t going to make a special entry for you on their DNS server

item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:9, topic:455025”]your router/modem should never go down. you may be confusing this with your IP lease expiring…[/quote]ah there is a lease thingy for seconds in my web configuration.

it’s set to like 860k atm

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

is there a setting in the web configuration tool for my cisco router that allows for longer times between restarting of the modem or anything? When I originally went to Best Buy and bought the Motorola modem I was told that the docis 2.0 disconnects too often and so I bought the docis 3.0

it still seems to disconnect/restart or whatever you call it about every 24-48 hours.

Read full topic

item.title: Comcast and static ip's
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:5, topic:455025”]Windows:

ipconfig /all

If it says “DHCP ENABLED: YES”
Your dynamic.

I believe for Linux its ifconfig.[/quote]
that’s his private network …

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:6, topic:455025”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=557889.msg4081594#msg4081594 date=1345418859]
Windows:

ipconfig /all

If it says “DHCP ENABLED: YES”
Your dynamic.

I believe for Linux its ifconfig.
[/quote]I already know I am dynamic babe <3

[quote author=t4 link=topic=557889.msg4081415#msg4081415 date=1345408195]

[quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=557889.msg4081414#msg4081414 date=1345408151]

you’d have to call your provider. generally, comcast offers static for business class only.
[/quote]so there is no way to use no-ip or something to host a server without getting business ? :s

you asked about static IPs… no-ip is a service that updates the DNS records for your domain (or a subdomain they provide) through software.
[/quote]so no-ip could be used ? The only issue I see here is that my modem tends to restart every 48 hours or so :s[/quote]
yes, but you’ll have downtime when your ip changes

Read full topic
